intro: Symphytum carmosina, commonly known as the Armenian beggar's tick, is a perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus and parts of Turkey. It is characterized by its hairy, upright stems and clusters of small, pale blue to purple flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has lance-shaped leaves with a rough texture and is often found in rocky or gravelly soils. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family, known for its medicinal properties and distinctive blue flowers. Symphytum carmosina is also noted for its ability to thrive in harsh, arid environments.
